sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: The GridSphere User's Guide describes how to install and configure GridSphere. For more information on developing and packaging portlets, please consult the GridSphere PortletReference Guide and the GridSphere Tutorials. The current implementation is based upon the GridSphere Technical Design Document. The GridSphere portal framework comes in both source and binary forms. Binaries can be created from the source code and in both cases, the build environment is generally the same. The GridSphere source code comes with a README file explaining how to build the binary distribution. Both source and binaries come packaged with all the necessary third party libraries and requires a GridSphere compatible servlet container, currently Tomcat 4.1+ and Tomcat 5 are supported

listitem.para: JDK 1.4.2 or JDK 1.3.1 &JDK; or JRE if you don't need to build any source. DO NOT USE JDK 1.4.1 since it contains a broken Xalan library.
Jakarta Ant 1.5.3-1+ &Ant; is used to compile and deploy the GridSphere framework

Jakarta Tomcat Servlet Container &Tomcat; 4.1+ or Tomcat 5 is required. (Currently, only Tomcat fully supports the Manager web application that allows for dynamic portlet management.) (Make sure you get the full Tomcat version and not the Light Edition (LE))

sect1.title: Bundled Software Packages
sect1.para: GridSphere uses many quality open source libraries listed below for completeness: It is not recommended to replace the bundled libaries.

listitem.para: &Castor; is used to provide Java to XML bindings
&Hibernate; is used to provide SQL based database support
&Cactus; provides a unit testing framework for testing GridSphere in a servlet container
&HSQL; database provides a pure Java SQL database
&Commons; utility classes for performing file uploads, etc.

sect1.title: Installing Jakarta Ant
sect1.para: In order to build the source distribution or deploy GridSphere to a Tomcat servlet container, you will need to download Jakarta Ant. Ant is also used to run the unit tests.

listitem.para: Unzip ant into your preferred location and set the ANT_HOME environment to point to this location
Copy junit.jar from your GRIDSPHERE_HOME/lib into ANT_HOME/lib (only necessary if you want to run the tests)
Add ANT_HOME/bin to your PATH environment

sect1.title: Installing Jakarta Tomcat
sect1.para: The Jakarta Tomcat servlet container is required to provide a hosting environment for the GridSphere framework.

listitem.para: Unzip tomcat into your preferred location and set the CATALINA_HOME environment to point to this location If using Windows, set the path with forward slashes e.g C:/MyApps/MyTomcat-4.29!

The Portlet Manager Portlet requires the Tomcat manager webapp to be configured to allow the gridsphere user to manage web applications. You must modify $CATALINA_HOME/conf/tomcat-users.xml and make sure the following line is there:
<user username="gridsphere" password="gridsphere" roles="manager"/>

To ensure that clients can't access the manager webapp directly, modify $CATALINA_HOME/conf/server.xml with the following where $CATALINA_HOME is replaced with the actual path to Tomcat e.g. "/usr/local/tomcat":
<Context path="/manager" debug="0" privileged="true" docBase="$CATALINA_HOME/server/webapps/manager"> <Valve className="org.apache.catalina.valves.RemoteAddrValve" allow="127.0.0.1"/> </Context>
Make sure there are no line-breaks between beginning and closing tags!
